name: Maddur Vada
history: Maddur Vada is a popular snack from Karnataka, named after the town of Maddur. It's known for its unique texture and flavor, combining elements of a crispy and a soft snack.
description: Maddur Vada is a savory fried snack made from a mixture of rice flour, semolina, and all-purpose flour, flavored with onions, curry leaves, and spices. It's crispy on the outside and soft inside.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine rice flour, semolina, all-purpose flour, onions, green chilies, curry leaves, cumin seeds, and salt. Add hot water gradually and knead into a stiff dough.

instructions.title: Shape the Vadas
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Flatten each ball into a disc shape.

instructions.title: Fry the Vadas
instructions.description: Heat oil in a frying pan. Fry the vadas until golden brown and crispy.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Maddur Vadas hot with chutney or ketchup.

tips: Ensure the dough is not too moist; it should be stiff for the vadas to hold their shape.
Fry on medium heat for even cooking and to achieve a crispy texture.
variations: Add grated vegetables like carrots or cabbage to the dough for a twist.
Experiment with different spices like asafoetida or garlic for added flavor.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh but can be stored in an airtight container for up to 1 day.
storage.instructions: Store at room temperature and reheat in a microwave or on a stovetop.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in a microwave or on a stovetop until crispy.
presentationTips: Serve on a platter garnished with sliced onion and lemon wedges.
Accompany with a colorful array of chutneys for dipping.
